title: Blended Elementary Language Education Design: Comparing Language Acquisition Effects of Computer vs. Face-to-Face Learning – Focus on Vocabulary, Grammar, and Expressive Fluency

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational language education theories (listening/speaking instruction principles, integrated reading/writing approaches) and practical experience in elementary language education, along with basic understanding of language learning support in digital environments.
context.additional_context: Strengthening blended learning design competencies in smartphone-based limited-technology environments, focusing on enhancing learners’ digital adaptability and language expression skills (writing, speaking). Emphasis is on activity design for grammar internalization and vocabulary expansion.

learning_goals: Compare and analyze language acquisition characteristics (vocabulary expansion, grammatical internalization, expressive fluency) between computer-based and face-to-face learning, evaluating their impacts on language proficiency (reading/writing/listening/speaking)

Design effective blended language learning strategies considering digital literacy levels in resource-constrained environments, improving learners' grammatical comprehension and vocabulary utilization

Develop integrated lesson plans incorporating reading/writing/listening/speaking activities in language education contexts, establishing specific activity plans reflecting text analysis and expression strategies

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
